Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "[tests] change NUnit result format on Windows" (#1680) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/index?buildId=1685026

On master, Windows builds have been frequently timing out on the
completion of the Xamarin.Android.Build.Tests NUnit tests:

    2018-05-14T16:11:30.6755378Z   Test Run Summary
    2018-05-14T16:11:30.6755639Z     Overall result: Warning
    2018-05-14T16:11:30.6755977Z     Test Count: 314, Passed: 275, Failed: 0, Warnings: 0, Inconclusive: 0, Skipped: 39
    2018-05-14T16:11:30.6756344Z       Skipped Tests - Ignored: 39, Explicit: 0, Other: 0
    2018-05-14T16:11:30.6758931Z     Start time: 2018-05-14 15:48:47Z
    2018-05-14T16:11:30.6772121Z       End time: 2018-05-14 16:11:30Z
    2018-05-14T16:11:30.6772666Z       Duration: 1362.691 seconds
    2018-05-14T16:11:30.6772900Z
    2018-05-14T16:11:30.6989428Z   Results (nunit2) saved as TestResult-Xamarin.Android.Build.Tests.xml
    2018-05-14T19:34:35.2647344Z Attempting to cancel the build...
    2018-05-14T19:34:40.2864864Z ##[warning]build-tools\scripts\RunTests.targets(30,5): Warning MSB4220: Waiting for the currently executing task "Exec" to cancel.

VSTS is hitting the 4 hour build timeout we have configured, and so
VSTS is cancelling the running `<Exec />` MSBuild task. It is very
strange, because it seems to be timing out *after* it starts writing
the test results file...

Since the tests appear to be completed, seeing if using the default
`nunit3` result format on Windows will solve the problem.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support ConstraintLayout in the VS Designer" (#1625) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new project
2. Change the Main view to use ConstraintLayout
3. Switch to the designer

<!--
If you have a repro project, you may drag & drop the .zip/etc. onto the issue editor to attach it.
-->

### Expected Behavior

I can use the designer as usual, with drag&drop and etc.

### Actual Behavior

One of those three, depending on Xamarin's mood:

1. A mock view labeled "ConstraintLayout"
2. A red screen
3. A correctly rendered view, but unable to be edited (unable to use drag&drop)

### Version Information
Visual Studio 2017, Xamarin 8.1, Xamarin.Android.Support.Constraint.Layout 1.1.0 Nuget package

> VS bug [#609834](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/609834)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Android] Release build crashes on launch" (#2671) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description
When deploying a release build to a device with either "ProGuard" or "Bundle assemblies into native code" enabled, the app crashes on launch.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new Xamarin Forms Mobile App.
2. Change solution configuration to Release.
3. Under Android options, enabled either "ProGuard" or "Bundle assemblies into native code".
4. Deploy to a **device.**

### Expected Behavior
App to launch successfully.

### Actual Behavior
Crashes on launch.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 3.0.0.446417
- Last known good version: 2.5.1.527436
- IDE: Visual Studio Enterprise 2017 v15.7.1
- Platform Target Frameworks:
  - Android: 8.1

.NET Framework 4.7.2
Android SDK Platform-Tools 27.0.1
Android SDK Build-Tools 27.0.3
Proguard 6.0.3
JDK 8 Update 171
Android NDK R17

### Reproduction Link

[App1.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/1994395/App1.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Android] Include basic proguard file so starting Xamarin Forms project can release with proguard enabled" (#2709) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description
The current starter Xamarin Forms Android project will not deploy as is with proguard enabled. 

The minimum configuration currently required is a proguard file with the following entry

```
-keep class android.support.v7.widget.FitWindowsFrameLayout { *; }
-dontwarn android.support.v7.widget.FitWindowsFrameLayout
```

The support libraries all include proguard.txt files as part of their nuget packages so Xamarin Forms could also include the above minimum.

It is debatable whether this is useful since as a user grows and application and uses more things they are going to have to learn how to interact with proguard and modify the file. It is just the inevitable outcome of having proguard enabled


### Steps to Reproduce
- Create a new Xamarin Forms Mobile App.
- Under Android options, enabled either "ProGuard" 
- Set Linker to Link SDK Assemblies
- Deploy to a **device.**

### Expected Behavior
App to launch successfully.

### Actual Behavior
Crashes on launch.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 3.0.0.446417
- Last known good version: 2.5.1.527436
- IDE: Visual Studio Enterprise 2017 v15.7.1
- Platform Target Frameworks:
  - Android: 8.1

.NET Framework 4.7.2
Android SDK Platform-Tools 27.0.1
Android SDK Build-Tools 27.0.3
Proguard 6.0.3
JDK 8 Update 171
Android NDK R17

### Reproduction Link

[App1.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/1994395/App1.zip)

### RELATED Tickets
https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/issues/2671
https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/issues/2491
https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/issues/2457
https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/issues/2495

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Xamarin Forms Android app crash on boot in Release config with ProGuard on after updated to 27.0.2" (#2491) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
This happens after I upgraded `Xamarin.Android.Support.*` packages to version 27.0.2. App works when I build and run in Debug but failed when published to the Store. I tried Release config and it indeed crashes on boot

I followed the suggestion here https://bugzilla.xamarin.com/show_bug.cgi?id=36287 and turned off ProGuard for Release config

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create Xamarin Forms project
2. Update all packages to the latest version
3. Turn on Proguard in Release Config
4. Build in Release and deploy to physical device

### Expected Behavior

Not crash on boot

### Actual Behavior

Crash on boot

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: `Xamarin.Android.Support.*` 27.0.2
- Last known good version: `Xamarin.Android.Support.*` 26.1.0.1
- IDE: VS for Mac 7.4.3 (build 10) Stable Channel
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - iOS:  <!-- The version of the iOS SDK you are compiling against, e.g. 11.1 -->
  - Android: target API Level 27
  - UWP:  <!-- The version of the UWP SDK you are compiling against, e.g. 16299 --> 
- Android Support Library Version: <!-- if applicable -->
- Nuget Packages: Xamarin.Forms 2.5.0.280555
- Affected Devices: all Android versions

### Screenshots

<!-- If the issue is a visual issue, please include screenshots showing the problem if possible -->

### Reproduction Link

<!-- Please upload or provide a link to a reproduction case -->

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "StyleSheet Reference Tag Throws Build Error. " (#2708) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
    <ContentPage.Resources>
        <StyleSheet Source="/Assets/Style/style.css" />
    </ContentPage.Resources>

The above code is causing the application to fail during build with a generic error message. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1.  Browse to https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/issues/1552. At the bottom of the page, find the CSS.zip file. Download and open Xamarin Project. 
2.  Attempt to Build and Deploy project to via Xamarin Live or an emulator.  
3.  Error is Thrown. Build Fails.

This also occurs on the Monkey CSS Project as well. 

### Expected Behavior
1. Project Successfully Builds. 
2. CSS is properly referenced in the app and effects the styling of the app.


### Actual Behavior
1. Build Fails. Throws the same error message as reported in 1552. The Same issue is references in Ticket 1553. 

The behavior also occurs with the Monkey CSS Example App. https://developer.xamarin.com/samples/xamarin-forms/UserInterface/Styles/MonkeyAppCSS/

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: Xamarin.Forms 3.0.0.446417
[Xamarin-StyleSheet-Issue-ScreenShots.docx](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/2003481/Xamarin-StyleSheet-Issue-ScreenShots.docx)

- Last known good version: Unknown.

### Screenshots
Attached

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add net461 support to Xamarin.Forms.Build.Tasks" (#2706) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description of Change ###

This adds net461 support to XFBT and makes use of Xamarin.Forms.Build.Tasks built with net461 when MSBuildRuntimeType is not 'Core'. 
This is a temporary solution before net471 is fully settled.

### Bugs Fixed ###

Fixes https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/issues/2690

### API Changes ###

N/A

### Behavioral Changes ###

N/A

### PR Checklist ###

- [ ] Has tests (if omitted, state reason in description)
- [X] Rebased on top of the target branch at time of PR
- [X] Changes adhere to coding standard
- [X] Consolidate commits as makes sense

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Adding a stylesheet causes a build error" (#2705) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description

I'm adding a css stylesheet programatically to my forms page following the documentation on the microsoft website. The stylesheet is in the Assets directory of the .NET Standard forms project and set to be an embedded resource.

When I try to compile, I get the error "StyleSheet does not exist in the current context". Looking at intellisense, this does seem to be true - there is no StyleSheet class.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a XAML page.
2. In the code behind add

Resources.Add(StyleSheet.FromAssemblyResource(IntrospectionExtensions.GetTypeInfo(typeof(StyledPage)).Assembly, filename));

(filename is the full path to the css file)

### Expected Behavior

Code compiles as per the Microsoft example

### Actual Behavior

Compiler fails to build saying "StyleSheet not found in this context" - it makes no difference if Resources is preceded or not by this.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 3.0.0.446417
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - iOS:  10+
  - Android: 8.1

### Reproduction Link

https://github.com/nodoid/multisheets/tree/master

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Page doesn't render" (#2704) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
Page doesn't render if init navigation not in constructor

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create Xamarin Forms app with Android and wpf projects.

2 In Xamarin Forms app change method to this
public App()
        {
            InitializeComponent();
            InitApp();     // used for DI        
        }

protected override async void OnStart()
        {
            base.OnStart();
            await  InitNavigation();
            OnResume();
        }

private static Task InitNavigation()
        {
            var navigationService = IoC.Container.GetInstance<INavigationService>();
            return navigationService.InitializeAsync(); // Navigate to page NavigateToAsync<MainViewModel>()
        }

3. Run on Android. The page is rendered.
4. Run on WPF. The page is not rendered

### Expected Behavior
Page is rendered on wpf

### Actual Behavior
The page can be rendered on WPF if run InitNavigation on Constructor

public App()
        {
            InitializeComponent();
            InitApp();
            InitNavigation();          
        }

protected override async void OnStart()
        {
            base.OnStart();
            OnResume();
        }
### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 3.1.0.469394-pre1, the same on previous
- Last known good version:
- IDE: VS2017 15.7.1
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - iOS:  <!-- The version of the iOS SDK you are compiling against, e.g. 11.1 -->
  - Android: <!-- The version of the Android SDK you are compiling against, e.g. 7.1 --> 
  - UWP:  <!-- The version of the UWP SDK you are compiling against, e.g. 16299 --> 
- Android Support Library Version: <!-- if applicable -->
- Nuget Packages:
- Affected Devices:

### Screenshots

<!-- If the issue is a visual issue, please include screenshots showing the problem if possible -->

### Reproduction Link

<!-- Please upload or provide a link to a reproduction case -->

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The contents of response files aren't taken into account when determining whether the cache is still valid or not" (#4033) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Repro:

0. Enable diagnostic build log.
1. Create a new project.
2. Add something to the additional mtouch arguments (for instance `-gcc_flags -v`).
3. Build
4. Change the additional mtouch arguments (for instance to `-gcc_flags -v -v`).
5. Build again. The build log should state that the cache was cleared:

> A full rebuild has been forced because the cache for ... is not valid.

Support for response files was added in d15-7, and since we changed the MSBuild tasks to write arguments into response files, this is a functional regression.

> VS bug [#611119](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/611119), VS bug [#611121](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/611121)

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[d15-7] Fix default values for touchbar APIs in NSTextViewDelegate. (#3843)" (#4071) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Closed issue "AOT failure if ref readonly with generics is used" (#4077) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

Compile attached project in **Debug**

### Expected Behavior

It compiles

### Actual Behavior

It doesn't compile. Fails on AOTing

### Environment

```
Xamarin.iOS
Version: 11.10.1.177 (Visual Studio Community)
Hash: 7e782c1e
Branch: d15-7
Build date: 2018-04-25 15:27:13-0400
```

### Build Logs

```
/Users/antonl/Projects/monosyne/Samples/Scene/Projects/IOS/MTOUCH: Error MT3001: Could not AOT the assembly '/Users/antonl/Projects/monosyne/Samples/Scene/Projects/IOS/obj/iPhone/Debug/mtouch-cache/64/Build/Scene.exe' (MT3001) (Scene.IOS)
```
### Example Project (If Possible)

[Scene.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/files/1995134/Scene.zip)

### Important Code 

```
public ref readonly Components<T> GetComponents()
{
    return ref _components;
}
```

### Steps to Reproduce

IPA submitted to Apple for review crashes on startup. Cannot reproduce locally, only with the Release IPA; cleaned the solution and re-submitted, startup crash persists. Crash log contains the following line:

May  4 16:47:50 iPhone-8plus MasterLinkiOS[407] <Notice>: Xamarin.iOS: Could not find the assembly 'Xamarin.iOS.dll' in the app. This is usually fixed by cleaning and rebuilding your project; if that doesn't work, please file a bug report: http://bugzilla.xamarin.com

The app is already published to the App Store, this is just an updated version.

### Expected Behavior
App works correctly.

### Actual Behavior
See above

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Crash when setting RenderingApi on SCNRenderingOptions" (#4087) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
The key for `RenderingApi` seems to be incorrect on iOS 11.3 and using it results in an ArgumentNull exception.

### Steps to Reproduce

```
new SCNView (UIScreen.MainScreen.Bounds, new SCNRenderingOptions {
            RenderingApi = SCNRenderingApi.Metal,
        })
```

1. Run that code on iOS 11.3
2. Note the crash

### Expected Behavior

SCNView is created with Meta.

### Actual Behavior

Crash

```
System.ArgumentNullException: Value cannot be null.
Parameter name: key
  at Foundation.DictionaryContainer.NullCheckAndRemoveKey (Foundation.NSString key, System.Boolean removeEntry) [0x0001e] in /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/11.10.1.174/src/Xamarin.iOS/Foundation/DictionaryContainer.cs:330 
  at Foundation.DictionaryContainer.SetNumberValue (Foundation.NSString key, System.Nullable`1[T] value) [0x00000] in /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/11.10.1.174/src/Xamarin.iOS/Foundation/DictionaryContainer.cs:390 
  at SceneKit.SCNRenderingOptions.set_RenderingApi (System.Nullable`1[T] value) [0x00009] in /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/11.10.1.174/src/Xamarin.iOS/SceneKit/SCNRenderingOptions.cs:20 
```

### Environment

```
=== Visual Studio Enterprise 2017 for Mac (Preview) ===

Version 7.5 Preview (7.5 build 1222)
Installation UUID: 4ba352e1-73e8-4dab-a9db-28012ca05af8
Runtime:
	Mono 5.10.1.47 (2017-12/8eb8f7d5e74) (64-bit)
	GTK+ 2.24.23 (Raleigh theme)
	Xamarin.Mac 4.4.0.36 (master / 0c7c49a6)

	Package version: 510010047

=== NuGet ===

Version: 4.3.1.4445

=== .NET Core ===

Runtime: /usr/local/share/dotnet/dotnet
Runtime Versions:
	2.1.0-preview2-26406-04
	2.0.3
SDK: /usr/local/share/dotnet/sdk/2.1.300-preview2-008530/Sdks
SDK Versions:
	2.1.300-preview2-008530
	2.0.3
MSBuild SDKs: /Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/Versions/5.10.1/lib/mono/msbuild/15.0/bin/Sdks

=== Xamarin.Profiler ===

Version: 1.6.2
Location: /Applications/Xamarin Profiler.app/Contents/MacOS/Xamarin Profiler

=== Apple Developer Tools ===

Xcode 9.3 (14154)
Build 9E145

=== Xamarin.Mac ===

Version: 4.4.1.173 (Visual Studio Enterprise)

=== Xamarin.Android ===

Version: 8.3.0.18 (Visual Studio Enterprise)
Android SDK: /Users/fak/Library/Developer/Xamarin/android-sdk-macosx
	Supported Android versions:
		7.0 (API level 24)
		7.1 (API level 25)
		8.1 (API level 27)

SDK Tools Version: 26.1.1
SDK Platform Tools Version: 26.0.2

Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.152-b16, mixed mode)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Xamarin.iOS Binding for native SDK gets "ObjCRuntime\Trampolines.g.cs" class file broken" (#4086) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
I implemented a Xamarin.iOS binding library using Sharpie for a mobile SDK native available for iOS only.

I ran over most of the documentation about Sharpie but I'm facing this issue when building the project:

* After creating the binding and use it for a Xamarin.Forms (iOS only) it It gets a compiling issue for a generated class file. 
* I'm able to fix it manually by changing the misinterpreted type to a "var" and that's it.
* Unfortunately, my CI pipeline can't do that so it gets broken builds too.

Output file in VS for Mac
../[ProjectName.iOS]/obj/Debug/ios/ObjCRuntime/Trampolines.g.cs

![Trampolines.cs](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/DZd9BKJWsAEsoDW.jpg)
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a Xamarin binding project
2. Bring a .framework file
3. Use Sharpie for creating the Binding
4. Reference your new binding as part of a Xamarin iOS project (aka Xamarin.Forms flavored project)
5. Clean All and build the project

### Expected Behavior
Building the Xamarin Binding shouldn't bring up compiling issues on internal/generated tooling classes

### Actual Behavior
Local development build broken, CI/CD pipeline got broken too

### Environment
VS For Mac

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[msbuild] Adds minimum support for XM binding projects from VS" (#4080) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Minimum support means:
- Letting users open XM binding projects
- Building XM binding projects offline (not connected to the Mac)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[xharness] Create simulators if they don't already exist." (#4085) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Create any needed simulators, instead of relying on them already existing (or
someone manually creating them).

A nice side effect is that it will become possible to delete all simulators on
a bot (to reclaim space), and they'll be re-created when needed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[xharness] Don't make a potentially blocking call to enumerate device candidates in VerifyRun." (#4084) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Enumerating device candidates can block (if the devices haven't been populated
yet), so make the whole thing async-based instead.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[xharness] Wait for a build to finish even if it has started." (#4083) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Because build tasks might be shared between tests, and if another test already
started a build, this test must still wait until the build finishes.
